title: Help us reproduce a questionable study
description: Are 25 year olds really more random than 60 year olds?

slides.hed: We found this cool study about randomness that we wanted to show you.
slides.problem: But…there seems to be something a little fishy about the results, even though it was published in a peer-reviewed journal. Can you help us reproduce the study and figure things out?
slides.repeat: Although you’ve been here before, you can play again for fun if you’d like.

slides.name: toss
slides.prompt: Tap a sequence of 12 coin flips. Make it look as random as possible; another person should think it really happened.
slides.instructions: This experiment investigates how humans produce and perceive randomness. It consists of three very short tasks related to chance. A suggested pace is one tap per second.

slides.text: The study received coverage across dozens of outlets. The headline: A person’s ability to be random peaks around 25 years old and declines after 60.
We initially set out to use the findings to make an age guessing game, but after our analysis we lost confidence that it would yield good results.

We don’t think the study’s findings are reproducible because of the researchers’ decision to include questionable responses. To us, this meant the participant either misunderstood the instructions, or intentionally sabotaged the experiment.
The decision to include questionable responses was the difference between “ah this is interesting” and “welp, nothing here” (or “null results” in statistics lingo).
Here is the wording of the instructions from in the original study:
And here are examples of a <mark class=good>good</mark> and <mark class=bad>questionable</mark> dice roll sequence based on their classifying algorithm.

Do you think the questionable response looks genuinely random and satisfies the instructions? We don’t. The researchers behind the study did (and confirmed it via email). And this disagreement has a big statistical impact.
Here is the key chart from the study that shows the developmental curve of complexity for the coin toss experiment.

steps.text: Think of the complexity score as a proxy for randomness; higher up means more random, lower down means less random. Here are a few <mark class=good>examples</mark> (H for heads, T for tails).
Here is your score. Your answer got a higher random score than of people in the study.
When we add a <mark class=good>trend line,</mark> we can see the age drop-off finding take shape.
At the bottom are the <mark class=bad>questionable responses</mark>. We even took a conservative approach to defining questionable; just the sequences that were uniformly heads or uniformly tails.
When we exclude the questionable responses, the declining trend line disappears.

slides.text: That breakdown was just for the coin toss, but the downward curve looks the same for the aggregate results across all three tasks.

The study was peer-reviewed, but to our knowledge it hasn’t been reproduced. This is typical, since reproduction takes a significant amount of time and effort on the part of other scientists busy conducting their own research. It is quite likely that the reviewers didn’t personally replicate the authors’ data analysis either, which led the authors’ decision to include the questionable responses to remain unnoticed.
The experiment at the start of this story was our attempt at our own abridged reproduction. Here are the live results of that process from <mark></mark> (not questionable) reader responses.

Since this chart is being created on the fly, we can’t tell you what it looks like. But our hypothesis is that it is more or less a straight line. Are we right? If so, we haven’t found any correlation with age and randomness. If not, then perhaps there is something worth exploring further!

The moral of the story: just because you read a New York Times headline about a study doesn’t mean that its findings are replicable, so stay curiously skeptical. Maybe you knew that, in which case we hope you enjoyed this breakdown. Support The Pudding and more stories like this on Patreon.

methods.value: The calculation of algorithmic complexity is done using the CTM method. In practice, we use a custom implementation of the acss R package to obtain this complexity for given user inputs and compute an overall score.

For the task level data, we use the original dataset of the study and use a cutoff non-uniform responses to remove questionable ones. We then overlay this data with a trend line calculated using the LOESS (locally estimated scatterplot smoothing) method.
